awd_titl_txt: Geometry of Nonhomogeneous Random Matrices, Vectors, and Processes
awd_abstract_narration:
High-dimensional random structures arise throughout mathematics and its applications. Many classical problems of probability theory are devoted to understanding the patterns that are generated by random noise in high-dimensional systems. For example, suppose one has a large matrix each of whose entries is the outcome of an independent fair coin flip, i.e., the matrix is filled with noise. What do the eigenvalues of such a matrix look like? Such questions have beautiful answers that are now well understood. There are however many situations, both in pure and in applied mathematics, in which there is nontrivial structure underneath the noise. For example, in the random matrix problem, we could allow each entry to have an arbitrary variance that reflects the intensity of the corresponding variable. The challenge in such problems, which are much less well understood than their classical counterparts, is to capture the interplay between the structure and the noise. The aim of this project is to develop mathematical techniques that make it possible to address such questions in considerable generality. Beside their fundamental interest, such techniques are expected to be applicable to areas such as statistics and computer science where high-dimensional random structures play an important role. Several education and outreach activities further form a key part of this project.

The overarching goal of this project is to develop new mechanisms and techniques in high-dimensional probability to address problems that could be broadly characterized as having nonhomogeneous structure. The fundamental question in such problems is: how is the underlying geometric structure reflected in the probabilistic behavior of the model? Such questions are of significant importance in various pure and applied mathematical problems. This project aims to systematically investigate such problems that arise in three interrelated themes: (i) the norms of nonhomogeneous random matrices (for example, with arbitrary variance or sparsity pattern); (ii) the geometry of nonhomogeneous random processes (such as those that arise, for example, in random matrix theory or in functional analysis); (iii) geometric inequalities and dimension-free phenomena (for example, in connection with measure concentration or convexity). The project will leverage recent advances on these topics to push forward the state-of-the-art in this area of probability and its applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is concerned with the development of mathematical technology for understanding high-dimensional random and geometric structures that arise across many different disciplines. The project has resulted in major new developments in different directions that span several areas of mathematics. What these developments have in common is that they provide powerful tools for understanding the behavior of high-dimensional phenomena that arise in a diverse range of problems both of pure mathematics and in applied disciplines. Some highlights are described in further detail below. Beside its research outcomes, the project has contributed to mathematical education and workforce development through the creation of pedagogical materials and the training of graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs.

1. Random matrices

Random matrices appear in a surprisingly many situations. While they have their origin in physics, they play a central role in modern data science, statistics, machine learning, communication theory, and in the design of algorithms, as well as in pure mathematics.

In classical random matrix theory, one typically studies very simple special models, such as matrices whose entries are independent and identically distributed (i.e., "white noise"), and proves delicate exact asymptotic statements of the behavior of their spectrum in large dimension. In contrast, in many of the above applications, one is presented with a given random matrix (in a fixed dimension) that often exhibits some complicated structure. To date, the common wisdom has been that if one does not make very special model assumptions, one can only hope to say some very rough things about such matrices: e.g., give a rough order of magnitude of their eigenvalues.

This project developed a new viewpoint on this subject that upends this common wisdom. This new theory shows that one can take a given random matrix of essentially arbitrary structure, and associate with it a "platonic ideal" which is a certain deterministic operator for which all the relevant spectral information can be computed by explicit formulas. Under minimal conditions, the spectrum of the given random matrix will behave almost exactly like that of its platonic ideal. This  gives rise to a sharp nonasymptotic random matrix theory that captures almost arbitrarily structured matrices, and provides a powerful tool for applications.

2. Concentration inequalities

The concentration of measure phenomenon explains why nonlinear functions of many independent random variables tend to behave in an essentially nonrandom manner. This is familiar from experience: it explains why the world around us is highly predictable, even though it behaves randomly at microscopic scales. 

Classical concentration theory is concerned with scalar-valued functions. In many situations, one is interested in functions whose values are more complicated objects: for example, vector- or matrix-valued functions, where one aims to show they behave nonrandomly with respect to a suitable norm. Despite the potential importance of a theory of "vector concentration inequalities", a result of this kind was previously known only in the very special case of Gaussian measures, limiting its applicability.

This project initiated an entirely new approach to this problem which has made it possible to systematically develop a vector concentration theory that is applicable in many situations. The simplest instance of such an inequality, on the discrete cube, already settled a long-standing open problem in metric geometry due to Enflo (1978). Subsequent developments open the door to a general theory, with many potential applications in pure and applied mathematics.

3. Convexity

The project resulted in major progress on one of the oldest open problems in convex geometry, dating back to Minkowski (1903) and Alexandrov (1937). Minkowski realized that the classical isoperimetric theorem-which states that balls minimize surface area among all bodies of a given volume (this is why soap bubbles are round)-is a special case of a deep result about the coefficients of the volume polynomial, the Alexandrov-Fenchel inequality. Unlike in classical isoperimetry, however, balls are generally not the only minimizers. For example, if we fix both volume and mean width, the minimizers of surface area are "spiky balls" which are rather unusual. The question whether one can characterize all the extremals of the Alexandrov-Fenchel inequality has remained open since the earliest works in the subject.

This project developed fundamentally new techniques that made it possible to settle this problem in its most important cases: in the setting of convex polytopes, and in the general setting of Minkowski's inequality. It turns out that even the best known conjectures were incomplete, and many previously unknown extremals were discovered as part of this project. One of the most surprising aspects of this theory, however, are its unexpected connections with other areas of mathematics. For example, the results of this project settled a question of Stanley (1981) about log-concave sequence of integers that arise in the combinatorics of partially ordered sets, and have led to striking new progress on other combinatorial structures.
